metadata.title: Improving the postharvest performance of cut spray ‘Prince’ carnations by vase treatments with nano-silver and sucrose

sections.text:
NS plus 3% sucrose treatment provided the longest vase life extension (6.6 days) compared with the control, and significantly increased the anthocyanin content in floret petals. Besides, we also showed that the treatment with 5 mg L–1 NS alone or 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose significantly enhanced their vase solution uptake and relative fresh weight. Further, scanning electron microscopy observations revealed that the NS vase treatments evidently alleviated vascular occlusion by inhibiting bacterial colonisation and biofilm formation on their stemend cut surfaces and in the xylem vessels.
ARTICLE HISTORY Accepted 17 December 2018
KEYWORDS Bacterial xylem blockage; Dianthus caryophyllus; floret opening; nano-silver; spray carnation; vase life

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The carnation (Dianthus caryophyllus L.) is one of the most popular cut flowers, and given its high economic importance, holds a prominent position in the global flower industry (Naing, Win, Han, Lim, & Kim, 2017). Cut carnations are generally divided into two categories, i.e. the standard and spray types. Standard carnations have only one flower per stalk (stem), whereas spray carnations have a main stalk with several branches, each bearing one or two apical florets (Borochov & Mayak, 1984). In recent years, the demand for cut spray carnations has increased owing to their multiple and showy florets with diverse colours, types, and sizes (Hassanpour Asil, Karimi, & Zakizadeh, 2013; Satoh, Kosugi, Sugiyama, & Ohira, 2014).
Cut spray carnations are harvested with various florets on the stems at different stages of development, and the postharvest performance depends upon the successive opening of florets and their appearance quality (Borochov & Mayak, 1984; Begri, Hadavi, & Nabigol, 2014). Nevertheless, immature florets frequently fail to open normally and are prone to premature wilting during postharvest storage and display. In addition, performance is often adversely affected by petal wilting and discoloration (Satoh et al., 2014). The development of such symptoms is typically related to water stress
(Borochov & Mayak, 1984; Begri et al., 2014). The water-deficiency symptoms that develop in most cut flowers maintained in water are considered to arise from vascular blockage in the stems, primarily around the basal stem-ends, which can impede water uptake and supply to the flowers (Liu et al., 2014; Van Doorn, 2012). Stem blockage can result from bacterial proliferation, xylem cavitation, and physiological reactions to cutting (Van Doorn, 2012). Bacterial proliferation in vase solutions, particularly at the stem-ends of cut flowers, is predominantly responsible for stem blockage in many cut flowers (Li et al., 2017; Van Doorn, 2012). Furthermore, bacterial biofilms, which consist of bacteria embedded in the extracellular polysaccharide (EPS) matrices that they secrete, may form on the cut surface of stem-ends. Bacteria in biofilms are resistant to antibacterial agents and are hence difficult to eradicate, which potentially results in more severe vascular blockage and rapid withering of cut flowers and foliage (Li et al., 2017; Ratnayake, Joyce, & Webb, 2012). Inhibiting bacterial growth by supplementing vase water with various antimicrobial substances may delay flower wilting and prolong vase life (Van Doorn, 2012). Additionally, symptoms of disorder, such as incomplete floret opening and petal discoloration, during the display life of cut spray carnations may still be related to sugar deficiency (Borochov & Mayak, 1984; Begri

et al., 2014). The provision of exogenous sucrose can promote flower opening and anthocyanin synthesis in various cut flowers, including cut spray carnations (Borochov & Mayak, 1984; Arrom & Munné-Bosch, 2012; Gholami, Rahemi, & Rastegar, 2011).
Nano-silver (NS) has gained increasing attention as a novel antimicrobial agent (Tran, Nguyen, & Le, 2013). It has strong antimicrobial activity and is relatively friendly to the environment, and has thus been widely applied in various fields, including medicine, the textile industry, and water disinfection (Tang et al., 2017; Tran et al., 2013). Several studies have shown that postharvest treatments with NS can effectively suppress bacterial proliferation and extend the vase lives of various cut flowers and foliage (Hashemabadi, 2014; Li et al., 2012; Liu et al., 2009; Liu, Ratnayake, Joyce, He, & Zhang, 2012; Liu et al., 2014; Naing et al., 2017; Solgi, Kafi, Taghavi, & Naderi, 2009; Xia, Zheng, Zhao, & Wang, 2017). Li et al. (2017) recently showed that NS pulse treatment can alleviate vascular occlusion of cut gladiolus ‘Eerde’ spikes by inhibiting bacterial colonisation and biofilm formation at their stem-ends. In the case of cut standard carnations, some researchers have already demonstrated that NS (as a pulse and/ or vase solution treatment) can delay flower senescence and extend the vase life (Hashemabadi, 2014; Liu et al., 2014; Naing et al., 2017).
Although increasing studies have been on the effects of NS postharvest treatments on some cut flower crops, including cut standard carnations, there has been little knowledge of the positive effects of the combinations of NS and sucrose. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, there are no reports about the effects of NS alone and NS plus sucrose on cut spray carnations. Hence, in the present study, we investigated the potentially beneficial effects of vase treatments with NS alone and NS plus sucrose on the quality attributes of cut spray carnations. Assessment of the treatments was based on their effects on vase life, floret opening, petal anthocyanin contents, water relations, and bacterial stem blockage with regards to the typical water- and sugar-deficiency symptoms of cut spray carnations.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text:
Recently harvested cut ‘Prince’ spray carnation (D. caryophyllus L.) stems at the typical commercial stage (i.e. leading floret at Stage 2; see Figure 1(a)) were purchased from a cut-flower market in Guangzhou City, PR China. They were immediately stood upright in plastic buckets partially filled with tap water and transported within 1 h to the postharvest laboratory. The cut spray carnation stems were covered with a plastic film to prevent
mechanical damage and minimise water loss during transit. Upon arrival, uniform and healthy stems free of visual defects were selected for use in the experiments. Prior to initiating treatments, the stems were re-cut under deionised water (DIW) to a length of 25 cm, such that only four florets remained on each stem.
As described by Liu et al. (2012), colourless neutral concentrated NS solution (3000 mg L−1, pH 7.0 ± 0.5; 9.4 ± 2.5 nm particle diameter), obtained from Shanghai Huzheng Nano Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China), was used in the experiments. Sucrose (analytical grade) was purchased from Guangzhou Chemical Reagent Factory.
Experimental design and vase treatments
Based on a series of pilot experiments for optimising the treatments of NS alone or the combinations of NS and sucrose, three vase experiments were concurrently performed with the same batch of cut spray carnations.
Experiment 1: vase life evaluation Cut flowering stems were individually held in 250-mL glass vases, each containing 150 mL of the following vase solutions: DIW (control); 1, 2, or 5 mg L–1 NS; 5 mg L–1 NS plus 2%, 3%, or 4% (w/v) sucrose, respectively. Each treatment unit consisted of 10 cut flowering stems, of which 8 replicate stems were used for the assessment of vase life, and measurement of vase solution uptake, and relative fresh weight of each treatment.
Experiment 2: changes in petal anthocyanin content over vase period Cut flowering stems were individually held in 250-mL glass vases, each containing 150 mL of DIW (control), 5 mg L–1 NS, and 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% (w/v) sucrose, respectively. The measurement of petal anthocyanin content were performed in triplicate (i.e. three samples of petals were collected from three individual cut flowering stems for each treatment).
Experiment 3: scanning electron microscope (SEM) observations on stem bacterial xylem blockage Cut flowering stems were individually held in 250-mL glass vases, each containing 150 mL of DIW (control), 5 mg L–1 NS, and 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% (w/v) sucrose, respectively. The SEM observations on stem bacterial xylem blockage were performed in triplicate (i.e. three samples of stem-ends were collected from three individual cut flowering stems for each treatment).
All vase solutions were freshly prepared at the beginning of the experiments and were not renewed thereafter. The mouth of each vase was covered with a sheet of low-density polyethylene film to prevent
vase solution contamination and evaporation. Vases with cut flowers were arranged on benches in a randomised complete block design. The experiments were conducted in a dedicated vase life evaluation room at 20 ± 2°C, 60 ± 10% relative humidity, and 12 μmol m−2 s−1 light intensity (cool white florescent tubes) with a daily photoperiod of 12 h.

sections.heading: Vase life
sections.text:
Cut spray carnations were assessed daily for visual appeal during the vase life evaluation period. Vase life was evaluated according to the method of Begri et al. (2014), with a slight modification. The vase life was calculated as the number of days after placing the flower stems in vase
solutions (designated as day 0) untilmore than 50%of the florets had lost turgor and/or the pedicels bent or broke.

sections.heading: Petal anthocyanin content
sections.text:

The proximal outer petals were sampled in triplicate from florets of an individual inflorescence on days 0, 3, 6, 9, and 19 of the vase period. For each sample, 0.5 g of petal slices was extracted for 4 h with 10 mL of 100% methanol containing 1% (v/v) HCl solution in a thermostatic water bath at 37°C. sections.heading: SEM observations
sections.text: Bacterial colonisation and biofilm formation on the cut-end surface and in xylem vessels of cut spray carnations were observed by SEM according to the method of Li et al. (2017). Segments of approximately 5 mm in length were excised with razor blades from the base of each stem on day 0, 3, and 6 of the vase period from the control, 5 mg L–1 NS, and 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose groups. The stem segments were immediately placed into an FAA fixative mixture (70% alcohol: glacial acetic acid: 37%–40% formalin at a ratio of 90: 5: 5) and aspirated overnight. The samples were dehydrated in a graded series of 70%, 80%, 90%, and 100% ethanol, and thereafter were treated by using CO2 critical-point drying and sputter coating with gold. Sample surfaces were examined at a 15-kV accelerating voltage using a JSM-6360LV SEM (JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) and photographed.

sections.heading: Statistical analyses
sections.text: The data were analysed using DPS statistical software, version 9.5 (DPS Inc., Zhejiang, PR China). Diagrams were produced using SigmaPlot 11.0 (Systat Software Inc., San Jose, CA, USA). Means were compared using the least significant difference (LSD) test at the 0.05 probability level.

sections.heading: Results
sections.text: Effects of NS treatments on vase performance

sections.heading: Vase life
sections.text: The vase life of cut spray carnations was significantly extended by the various NS treatments compared with that of the control (Table 1). Among the three vase treatments with NS alone, 5 mg L–1 NS promoted the longest vase life extension of 4.6 d (40.7% extension) compared with the control, although this treatment did not differ significantly from the 2 mg L–1 NS treatment. The combinations of NS and sucrose further extended the vase life, particularly the 5mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose treatment, which prolonged vase life by 6.6 d relative to the control (58.4% extension). Nevertheless, no significant differences were observed between either of the other two NS plus sucrose treatments and the 5 mg L–1 NS treatment.

sections.heading: Ornamental quality
sections.text: The ornamental quality of the cut spray carnations was effectively improved by various NS vase treatments, compared with that of the control (Figure 1(b)). The vase treatment with 5 mg L–1 NS alone promoted floret opening. In addition to promoting further improved floret opening, all three combinations of 5 mg L–1 NS and sucrose also strongly enhanced and maintained the bright pink floret coloration during the vase period, thereby markedly improving the overall display quality of the cut spray carnations. Although the efficacy was commensurate with treatment sugar concentration, no significant differences were observed between 3% and 4% sucrose in terms of floret opening and petal colour enhancement.

sections.heading: Petal anthocyanin contents
sections.text:
The petal anthocyanin content of cut spray carnations in the control, 5 mg L–1 NS alone, and 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose treatments increased until day 6 of the vase period and decreased thereafter (Figure 2). Nevertheless, throughout the vase period, the petal anthocyanin content of carnations treated with the NS plus sucrose was significantly higher than that of cut carnations of the control and NS alone. However,

no significant differences were found between the petal anthocyanin contents of carnations subjected to the control and 5 mg L–1 NS treatment.
Effects of NS treatments on vase solution uptake and RFW
The cut spray carnations treated with 5 mg L–1 NS and 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose had significantly higher vase solution uptake than the untreated control after day 4 of the vase period, although there were no significant differences between the 5 mg L–1 NS and 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose treatments (Figure 3(a)). Additionally, both the 5 mg L–1 NS alone and the 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose vase treatments effectively enhanced the RFW of the cut spray carnations (Figure 3(b)). After day 6 of the vase period, the RFW for the 5 mg L–1 NS treatment group was significantly higher than that of the control. Moreover, the RFW after the NS plus sucrose treatment was significantly greater than that after the NS alone treatment on day 5 of the vase period and thereafter.
Effect of NS treatments on bacterial colonisation and biofilm formation
SEM observations showed that, treatments with 5 mg L–1 NS alone and 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose evidently reduced bacterial colonisation and biofilm formation on the cut surfaces of stem-ends and in the xylem vessels of cut spray carnations (Figure 4). On day 0 of the vase period, the cut surfaces of stemends were very clear, and only a few bacteria were observed on the cut surfaces of stem-ends and in their xylem vessels (Figure 4(a, b)). By day 3 of the vase period, however, amorphous bacterial deposits and a biofilm were observed on the cut stem-ends of the control flowers, and a small number of bacteria
were also found in the xylem vessels (Figure 4(c)). On day 6 of the vase period, the cut surfaces of the control flowers were almost entirely covered with a bacterial biofilm, and the xylem vessels were significantly blocked (Figure 4(d)). In contrast, until day 3 of the vase period, few bacteria were observed on the cut surface or in the xylem vessels of stems subjected to the NS vase treatments (Figure 4(e, g)). Even by day 6, there were relatively few bacteria or their amorphous deposits on the cut ends of stems treated with NS alone, and particularly so after treatment with NS plus sucrose. In addition, only a slight bacterial blockage was observed in the xylem vessels (Figure 4(f, h)).

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
Termination of the vase life of cut spray carnations is typically characterised by incomplete opening of the florets, petal wilting and discoloration (Satoh et al., 2014). In this study, the various vase NS treatments significantly extended the vase life of cut ‘Prince’ spray carnations (Table 1). Nonetheless, compared with the NS alone treatment, the combinations of 5 mg L–1 NS and various concentrations of sucroseweremore efficient in prolonging the vase life of cut spray carnations. This result is consistent with the findings of Park et al. (2017), who demonstrated the synergistic effects of NS and sucrose in extending the vase life of standard-type ‘Edun’ carnations. Moreover, we observed that the NS plus sucrose treatments played a more prominent role in promoting the opening of florets, and particularly in enhancing the bright pink colour of floret petals, thereby markedly improving the display quality. We also observed that the improvement in floret colour in response to treatment with 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose was related to an increase in the anthocyanin content of the petals of cut spray carnations (Figures 1 and 2). Sugar is required bymany cut flowers, thereby enabling them to sustainmetabolic activity andmaintain ornamental quality (Arrom & Munné-Bosch, 2012; Gholami et al., 2011; Van Doorn, 2004). In the case of cut spray carnations, sugar depletion leads to postharvest disorder symptoms, such as incomplete floret opening andpetal discoloration, during the display life (Borochov & Mayak, 1984; Begri et al., 2014). Accordingly, in the present study, we demonstrated that inclusion of sucrose in the vase solutions as an exogenous sugar supply can promote flower opening and anthocyanin synthesis in cut spray carnations, as has previously been shownwith other cut flowers (Arrom &Munné-Bosch, 2012; Gholami et al., 2011).
Additionally, the cut spray carnations held in a vase solution containing 5 mg L–1 NS, either with or without 3% sucrose, showed equally significantly higher vase solution uptake (Figure 3(a)) than that of the DIW control. Similarly, Liu et al. (2014) reported that pulse treatment with 250 mg L–1 NS for 1 h significantly increased the vase solution uptake of
cut ‘Master’ standard carnations by improving hydraulic conductance in the stem-ends. NS is believed to act as an effective antimicrobial agent that can reduce bacterial growth and biofilm formation at the stem-ends (Li et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2012, 2014; Van Doorn, 2012). The positive effect of NS on vase solution uptake by cut spray carnations appeared to inhibit bacterial growth, which can be the major cause of vascular blockage in basal stem-ends and restrict their vase water supply (Liu et al., 2014; Lü et al., 2010; Van Doorn, 2012). Moreover, vase treatments with 5 mg L–1 NS, particularly in combination with 3% sucrose, significantly enhanced the RFW of cut spray carnation flowers during the vase period (Figure 3(b)). Apparently, the beneficial effects of NS treatments on the RFW of cut spray carnations are associated with enhanced vase solution uptake.
The effect of NS treatments in alleviating the development of bacterial blockage in the stem-ends of cut
spray carnations was further corroborated by SEM observations (Figure 4). We observed that vase treatments with 5 mg L–1 NS alone and NS plus sucrose had equivalent and significant effects in terms of reducing bacterial colonisation and biofilm formation on the stem-end cut surface and in the xylem vessels. Li et al. (2017) have similarly observed that NS pulse treatments significantly reduced both the numbers of bacteria and the quantity of their EPS, thereby inhibiting bacterial biofilm formation at the stem-ends of cut gladiolus ‘Eerde’ spikes during their vase period. The profound effects of NS vase treatments exhibited herein in alleviating bacterial blockage at the stemends of cut spray carnations are in accordance with our previous work, in which we examined the spatial and temporal distributions of NS in cut standard carnations subjected to NS pulse treatments, and also with earlier studies on cut roses, gerberas, and Acacia holosericea foliage (Li et al., 2012; Liu et al., 2012, 2014;

Vertical bars indicate the least significant difference test at the 0.05 probability level (LSD0.05; n = 8) for the treatment comparisons.

Lü et al., 2010). In these experiments, it was found that most of the NS remained at the basal stem-ends, in which it could exert powerful and sustainable antibacterial action throughout the vase period. Indeed, an increasing number of studies have clearly demonstrated that postharvest NS treatments can enhance the vase solution uptake of cut flowers and foliage, thereby alleviating their water-deficit symptoms (Li et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2009; Lü et al., 2010).
Considered collectively, the beneficial effects of NS treatments on cut spray carnations in improving their postharvest performance are evidently related to the strong reduction in bacterial proliferation and biofilm formation at the stem-ends. In addition, it has previously been suggested that Ag+ ions released fromNS are potent blockers of ethylene action, whichmight be an additional effect of NS treatments for ethylene-sensitive cut flowers (Hashemabadi, 2014; Naing et al., 2017). Similar to standard carnations, the previously examined cut spray carnation varieties have been shown to be sensitive to ethylene, with their petal wilting and flower senescence being associated with ethylene production and action (Begri et al., 2014; Hassanpour Asil et al., 2013; Satoh et al., 2014). Here, we observed that NS treatments (either with or without sucrose) significantly promoted floret opening, delayed petal wilting and senescence (Figure 1(b)), and extended the vase life (Table 1) of cut spray carnations. Thus, the beneficial effects of NS treatments might partially be attributed to antagonistic activity against the effects of ethylene.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: Vase treatments of cut ‘Prince’ spray carnations with NS, particularly in combination with sucrose, showed beneficial effects, including enhanced vase life, vase solution uptake and RFW, and delayed petal wilting and floret senescence. Moreover, the NS plus sucrose treatments prominently promoted floret opening and increased petal anthocyanin contents, therebymarkedly improving the display quality. Further, SEM observations revealed that NS vase treatments significantly alleviated vascular occlusion by evidently reducing bacterial colonisation and biofilm formation at the stem-ends. The positive effects of NS vase treatments may be partially attributed to the anti-ethylene action of NS; however, further investigations are required to examine and confirm this additional effect. Overall, the 5 mg L–1 NS plus 3% sucrose treatment prolonged vase life and improved the postharvest performance to a greater extent than the other treatments applied, and as such may serve as a practical and effective method for preserving cut spray carnations.

metadata.abstractText: The postharvest performance of cut spray-type carnations (Dianthus caryophyllus L.) is often limited by the opening, longevity, and coloration of individual florets, and is apparently related to water stress and sugar deficiency. In this study, we found that, compared with deionised water-treated controls, the vase life of cut spray ‘Prince’ carnations was extended by 2.1–4.6 days when held in vase solutions containing1–5 mg L nano-silver (NS). Moreover, combination treatments with 5 mg L NS and 2%, 3%, or 4% sucrose consistently further prolonged the vase life, prominently promoted floret opening, and increased the bright pink coloration of petals, thereby markedly enhancing quality performance. Overall, the 5 mg L NS plus 3% sucrose treatment provided the longest vase life extension (6.6 days) compared with the control, and significantly increased the anthocyanin content in floret petals. Besides, we also showed that the treatment with 5 mg L NS alone or 5 mg L NS plus 3% sucrose significantly enhanced their vase solution uptake and relative fresh weight. Further, scanning electron microscopy observations revealed that the NS vase treatments evidently alleviated vascular occlusion by inhibiting bacterial colonisation and biofilm formation on their stemend cut surfaces and in the xylem vessels.
